passage.from: I Have a Dream (1963 speech at the Lincoln Memorial)
passage.text: We have also come to this hallowed spot to remind America of the fierce urgency of now. This is no time to engage in the luxury of cooling off or to take the tranquilizing drug of gradualism. Now is the time to make real the promises of democracy. Now is the time to rise from the dark and desolate valley of segregation to the sunlit path of racial justice. Now is the time to lift our nation from the quicksands of racial injustice to the solid rock of brotherhood. Now is the time to make justice a reality for all of God's children.

sceneLoadVideo.label: Intro
sceneLoadVideo.transcript: Hi. I'm Henry. I live in New York City. I'm an artist - drawing and painting. I go to LaGuardia High School, which you might know from the movie Fame. I love reading cause it lets me experience places I've never been and lets me kinda get into the author's head and know how they're thinking or feeling.

sceneLoadVideo.label: Main Idea
sceneLoadVideo.transcript: Today we're going to look at a passage from Martin Luther King, Jr.'s famous 'I Have a Dream' speech. King was an activist, working for equal rights for African Americans in the United States. He gave this speech in front of the Lincoln Memorial in Washington DC in 1963 at an enormous rally to end racist laws and practices. If you care about everyone being treated equally and American ideals of democracy and liberty, you need to know this speech.

beforeTimeVideo.transcript: Did you hit that by accident? You actually have to read the passage.

sceneLoadVideo.label: Main Idea
sceneLoadVideo.transcript: First read the passage. Then we'll talk.

options.label: Totally!

Sort of...maybe?
No

sceneLoadVideo.transcript: Did you get this paragraph?
So, what's the main idea of this paragraph? Type a few words or phrases in the chat box
Thanks. We'll come back to the main idea after reading more closely.

multiChoice.question: Read sentence one. What does King mean by 'THIS hallowed spot'? What hallowed spot? ('Hallowed' means 'holy' or 'honored' btw.)

options.label: his carpentry shop in his garage
The Lincoln Memorial
The White House

onFinishByFailure.transcript: Nah. I mean, that COULD make sense, but it didn't SAY anything about that, so - no. Never make stuff up. He's giving the speech in front of the Lincoln Memorial, so he must be talking about that.

sceneLoadVideo.transcript: Read sentence one. What does King mean by 'THIS hallowed spot'? What hallowed spot? ('Hallowed' means 'holy' or 'honored' btw.)

multiChoice.question: So how does calling attention to the location - 'this hallowed spot' - the Lincoln Memorial - set the tone for King's words? Keep in mind that it was President Lincoln, who signed the Emancipation Proclamation, ending slavery in the United States...

options.label: It feels positive and serious
It feels exciting and relaxed.
It feels cautious and less confident.

onFinishByFailure.transcript: No - it makes it sound like a very big deal.

sceneLoadVideo.transcript: So how does calling attention to the location - 'this hallowed spot' - the Lincoln Memorial - set the tone for King's words? Keep in mind that it was President Lincoln, who signed the Emancipation Proclamation, ending slavery in the United States...

showQuotes.text: Brown vs. Board of Education made segregated schools illegal

sceneLoadVideo.transcript: The "now" King was talking about in 1963 included way more than this, but here are some responses that might give you an idea or remind you of some details.

options.label: he's saying we can't afford it
he'd be willing to trade his phone for it
"cooling off" comes in gold, platinum or titanium

onFinishByFailure.transcript: SMH - and, btw - no cell phones back then either

makes you feel insecure about yourself

config.question: Is King talking about an actual tranquilizer drug, like they use to put animals to sleep at the zoo?

sceneLoadVideo.transcript: Is King talking about an actual tranquilizer drug, like they use to put animals to sleep at the zoo?

sceneLoadVideo.transcript: So, what is King characterizing as a "tranquilizer drug"? Drag that phrase onto the word it's describing.

multiChoice.question: So, given that "gradualism" means taking things slowly, going gradually instead of pushing hard for a big change, what does King mean by calling it a tranquilizing drug?

options.label: Taking a slow approach to addressing a problem numbs you and makes you lose interest
The slow approach to a big problem is better cause it's less painful
It's better to take a slow approach so no one gets too upset

onFinishByFailure.transcript: Hmmmm... Is King FOR gradualism? No! He's saying, this is a huge problem, and we need to do somethinga about it now - not just wait around for it to slowly get better.

sceneLoadVideo.transcript: So, given that "gradualism" means taking things slowly, going gradually instead of pushing hard for a big change, what does King mean by calling it a tranquilizing drug?

onFinishByFailure.transcript: Nah. We're talking about the beginning of each of these sentences. See that? He repeats the phrase - "Now is the time..." "Now is the time..." "Now is the time..."

What impact does repeating that phrase over and over have? "now is the time..." "now is the time..." Type a phrase or two in the chat about what repeating that phrase does.

showQuotes.text: Reinforces the idea that its time for an action.
Words and thoughts that are repeated often get stronger by the repetitions

multiChoice.question: In the fifth sentence, King makes a contrast between..

options.label: "our nation" and "solid rock"
"quicksands of racial injustice" and "solid rock of brotherhood"
"Now is the time" and "quicksands of racial injustice"

onFinishByFailure.transcript: Nah. Those things don't really contrast. Use your navigator words. King says FROM the quicksand TO the solid rock.

sceneLoadVideo.transcript: In the fifth sentence, King makes a contrast between..

multiChoice.question: King didn't have to say "quicksand." How would the meaning change if he had said, "the fog of racial injustice" instead of the quicksand of racial injustice?

options.label: It would give a sense of confusion but not of serious danger.
It would be funny instead of serious.
It would make injustice seem physically dangerous instead of possibly okay.

onInCorrectMessages.transcript: Hm. Think about how things are hard to see in the fog. How's that different from being dragged down into quicksand.

onFinishByFailure.transcript: No. It's all about the contrast between thick fog that you can't see through and sand that drags you under and suffocates you!!

sceneLoadVideo.transcript: King didn't have to say "quicksand." How would the meaning change if he had said, "the fog of racial injustice" instead of the quicksand of racial injustice?

multiChoice.question: King didn't have to say "quicksand." How would the meaning change if he had said, "the fog of racial injustice" instead of the quicksand of racial injustice?

options.label: To show how close America was at the time to having true racial justice.

video.transcript: These images strongly contrast each other, so, if anything, they highlight how far America had to go still. Try again.

options.label: To emphasize how wrong inequality is and how good equality will be.
To show how nothing will every change no matter how hard people try.

onFinishByFailure.transcript: Nah. King's showing us how wrong racism is and how good equality will be.

onFinishByFailure.transcript: Check the end of each line. The promises of democracy, King says, are racial justice, brotherhood, and justice for all of God's children

What if King had skipped all the images and contrasts, left out the repeated "now is the time(s)" and just got right to point by replacing sentences three through six with a simple,  "We really need to achieve racial justice. Thank you for your time!" how would the tone have changed? Type your answer in the chat.

options.label: more enthusiastic but less detailed
factual but less passionate.
more emotional but less specific

onFinishBySuccess.transcript: True, it would take all the fire and urgency out of it.

sceneLoadVideo.transcript: Cool. Which of these best describes how this new version compares with what King actually said.

We're back to the main idea again. Here's what you said when we started. Wanna add anything?

options.label: People should try to end segregation right now, but it will take years to achieve.
Feeling inspired and empowered are all that people need to change the world.
If people fight for change right now they can finally bring about racial equality.

sceneLoadVideo.transcript: Okay. So, what's the main idea?
King felt urgency around civil rights, his activism and this speech helped to change the laws of the united states. What- if anything feels urgent to you today? Type your answer in the chat.

sceneLoadVideo.transcript: Did reading this closely help you understand the passage better?

default.transcript: Reading definitely takes a kind of an effort that other media don't. Video puts images directly into our brains. Easy. Reading takes more effort, cause our brains need to sound out the words and convert them into images and meanings. We call that ZINCING - taking words off the page and turning them into pictures and meanings in your head. Obviously, we all love to chill and just do easy stuff, but funny thing is, once you get comfortable with Zincing and other skills, your brain loves the effort of reading.

visualize.transcript: Your first reading move should always be to find words you can easily picture. Even in the most difficult text, a word or phrase you can picture is like a hand-hold when you're climbing a rock wall. Picture whatever you can, and then use those images to start figuring out what the whole text means.

key-images.transcript: If a writer says, "She had nice brown eyes," you just picture them, but, if she says, "She had brown eyes that sparkled like sunlight on glistening sea stones," you're getting a lot more to work with. You can imagine the brown eyes. You also picture sunlight on shiny stones in the sea. When you find a strong image like that, you wanna let yourself really see it. Then, when it's really happening in your imagination, you wanna notice all the other feelings and thoughts around that image. That's how you use a key image.

imagine.transcript: If a writer says, "She had brown eyes," you can easily visualize that. But when a writer says something less visual, like, "She hoped for good opportunities in her new home," you also need to picture something. What might these "opportunities" be? Think of something that makes sense and keep reading to find out more.

default.transcript: If you're driving a car, the paint on the road, the signs, the lights, signals from other cars - all this stuff tells you how to navigate. When you're reading, picking up the navigation clues let's you understand what the writer meant.

road-signs.transcript: Two types of road signs in a text - TRANSITION WORDS, like however, also, because, and - and punctuation - colons, semi-colons, commas, dashes and even periods. Mostly, the punctuation let's you know to expect an explanation or more details.

pronouns.transcript: Pronouns are words that act as place holders for other words - she, he, they, it, that, this. When you see a pronoun, make sure you connect it with the word or phrase it's replacing. "This led to blah, blah, blah..." What's "this"? You'll usually find pronouns replacing words or phrases that have just been mentioned or are about to be mentioned.

explainers.transcript: When a writer says something that's not completely clear, you should expect them to explain. Sometimes they give you punctuation, like a colon or dash or comma that announces, "here's the explanation!" Sometimes they just go on and explain.

default.transcript: Tone refers to the feelings behind the words. Is the author excited, or critical or angry or unsure? Look for words and phrases with a lot of flavor or contrasts between words to convey the writer's feelings.

contrast.transcript: Tone refers to the feelings behind the words. Is the author excited, or critical or angry or unsure? Look for words and phrases with a lot of flavor or contrasts between words to convey the writer's feelings.
